subNodes.conversationText: root
The innkeeper was busy, always on the move between the bar, the tables, and the stairs to the guests' quarters.
[Continue.]
"Ah, the witch," she said. "We've no rooms, unfortunately, but if you want a drink or some food you can speak to one of my underlings. Or do you have some other business you need me for?"
"Do any hunters come here regularly?"

"Many hunters pass through. But regulars? No. But I know old Sudder who lives to the north. He's come by once or twice. And I know of two others in the woods -- Wencel and... and I forget the other's name. I've never seen them, just heard word."
"What's Sudder like?"

But the innkeeper drew a line at sketching personalities. "I don't know what he's like," she said. "As far as I'm concerned, there's nothing remarkable about him, unless it's the fact that he has two young wives."
<FirstName> thanked her for the information.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
"I see. Have you heard any interesting news?"

"I don't have the time to listen, and most of it's foolishness. But I suppose it's no good brushing off a witch, so I'll tell you the little I do know. The Congress of Moths is at large -- that you can't help but know. The king of Dudow is in the region -- and that's something you might not have heard. And finally -- and this might be of more interest to you than to most people -- there's a witch hunter and magician out there, scouring the woods for someone named Zaurus."
"I see. By the way, I need someone to carry a message to the High Mayor of Enzibar as quickly as possible."

"You're in luck. A man can carry it south tomorrow morning." The innkeeper took the message, along with a few coins from the witch, and was putting it into a small chest when she saw the royal seal and froze.
<FirstName> thanked her for her time.
"Have you heard any interesting news?"

"I don't have the time to listen, and most of it's foolishness. But I suppose it's no good brushing off a witch, so I'll tell you the little I do know. The Congress of Moths is at large -- that you can't help but know. The king of Dudow is in the region -- and that's something you might not have heard. And finally -- and this might be of more interest to you than to most people -- there's a witch hunter and magician out there, scouring the woods for someone named Zaurus."
<FirstName> thanked her for her time.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
"I see. By the way, I need someone to carry a message to the High Mayor of Enzibar as quickly as possible."
"Ah. Do any hunters come here regularly?"

"Many hunters pass through. But regulars? No. But I know old Sudder who lives to the north. He's come by once or twice. And I know of two others in the woods -- Wencel and... and I forget the other's name. I've never seen them, just heard word."
"I need someone to carry a message to the High Mayor of Enzibar as quickly as possible."

"You're in luck. A man can carry it south tomorrow morning." The innkeeper took the message and a few coins from the witch. She was putting it into a small chest when she saw the royal seal and froze.
"As an innkeeper, you must know the value of not asking questions."

"Very well." She tucked the letter away.

<FirstName> hoped that it would make it to Enzibar in time to trick the minister.
"Thank you," said <FirstName>.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
[Continue,]
Now <FirstName> had to find the messenger with the minister's letter and somehow replace it with Astimund's forgery.
[End.]
"Thank you," said <FirstName>.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
[Continue.]

The young witch had done all <he/she> could. Whether the plan would work -- whether the news of the king's death would be delayed, and whether the diplomatic mission would continue on to Wan -- remained to be seen.
[End.]

The young witch had failed to steal the minister's letter to the princess, so it seemed unlikely that <his/her> success sending the other letter would mean much. The news of the king's death would soon spread like wildfire through Dudow.
[End.]
"I have friends in the royal family," the young witch lied. "One of them entrusted me to deliver this."

"Very well." She tucked the letter away.

<FirstName> hoped that it would make it to Enzibar in time to trick the minister.
The young witch said nothing.
"This seal --"
<FirstName> gave her a few more coins. "Make sure the messenger is trustworthy."

"Very well." She tucked the letter away.

<FirstName> hoped that it would make it to Enzibar in time to trick the minister.
"As an innkeeper, you must know the value of not asking questions."
"I have friends in the royal family," the young witch lied. "One of them entrusted me to deliver this."
The witch shook her head.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
[End.]
"Yes?" The innkeeper looked as busy as ever.
<FirstName> greeted her, then asked if she had any news.

"I don't have the time to listen, and most of it's foolishness. But I suppose it's no good brushing off a witch, so I'll tell you the little I do know. The Congress of Moths is at large -- that you can't help but know. The king of Dudow is in the region -- and that's something you might not have heard. And finally -- and this might be of more interest to you than to most people -- there's a witch hunter and magician out there, scouring the woods for someone named Zaurus."
<FirstName> greeted her, then asked if any of her regulars were hunters.

"Many hunters pass through. But regulars? No. But I know old Sudder who lives to the north. He's come by once or twice. And I know of two others in the woods -- Wencel and... and I forget the other's name. I've never seen them, just heard word."
"I need someone to carry a message to the High Mayor of Enzibar as quickly as possible."
"It's nothing," said the witch.
The innkeeper nodded and went back to work.
